meta.title: A Thousand Brains: A New Theory of Intelligence
meta.author: Jeff Hawkins

parts.title: Evolution of Brain Science and Thousand Brains Theory
parts.body: Neuroscience's quest to understand intelligence remains a mystery, despite collecting numerous facts about the brain. Jeff Hawkins explores this in "A Thousand Brains," proposing a breakthrough with the Thousand Brains Theory based on reference frames. Like a map with grid lines, these frames structure knowledge and thought, explaining sensory integration and false beliefs. With roots in Crick's ideas and Hawkins' own journey in Silicon Valley, this work links human and machine intelligence while pondering the future driven by either our genes or intellectual capacity.

parts.title: Journey from Tech to Neuroscience
parts.body: After hundreds of neuroscience papers, incorporating psychology, linguistics, and philosophy, the author gains a unique educational experience. In 1988, he starts entrepreneurial successes in Silicon Valley, creating tablet computers and founding Palm Computing, where handheld devices flourish. His passion, however, lies in neuroscience, specifically brain theory. The author eventually leaves his business endeavors to delve back into neuroscience. In 2002, with neuroscientist friends’ support, he establishes the Redwood Neuroscience Institute (RNI), concentrating on neocortical theory, collaborating with visiting scholars. Although RNI was successful, he yearns for consensus on specific questions. RNI is relocated to UC Berkeley, where it's welcomed despite earlier resistance, transforming into the Redwood Center for Theoretical Neuroscience. The author also creates Numenta, focusing on neocortex theories and applying them to machine learning. After significant discoveries in 2010 and 2016, he starts writing a book to share insights on the neocortex, emphasizing the importance of a few billion cells acknowledging the universe.

parts.title: Mountcastle's Universal Algorithm Theory
parts.body: Mountcastle's Big Idea: Vernon Mountcastle, in his 1978 essay "An Organizing Principle for Cerebral Function," proposed a revolutionary theory about the neocortex's role in intelligence. Instead of growing new distinct parts, the neocortex expands by replicating a basic circuit over and over, a concept akin to Darwin's evolution theory. Mountcastle suggested that all regions of the neocortex are fundamentally the same, doing the same thing but connected differently—leading to different functions like vision or language. Universal Algorithm: Mountcastle theorized a universal cortical algorithm responsible for all intelligent functions, focusing on cortical columns—thin strands within the neocortex, stacked like pieces of thin spaghetti. These columns, further divided into minicolumns, perform the same underlying function across all neocortical areas. This idea implies that varied cognitive abilities stem from the same computational process, casting the neocortex as a uniform system executing a single algorithm for perception and intelligence. Mountcastle's Influence: Despite some skepticism, Mountcastle's proposition remains a landmark in neuroscience. It offers a unified explanation for the neocortex's seemingly similar architecture across diverse tasks and animal species. The debate continues as many neuroscientists seek to decode the cortical column's function, holding it as a crucial element in understanding human intelligence. The essay's influence resonates profoundly with those exploring complex brain theories, presenting an elegant framework for pursuing brain research.

parts.title: The Importance of Reference Frames in the Neocortex
parts.body:
Reference Frames and Cortical Columns

This chapter highlights the essential function of reference frames in the neocortex—an insight explaining how the brain predicts the next input when we move. The author had an "aha moment" realizing that for the brain to make such predictions, it needs to know object location in its reference frame, and this spurs predictions of subsequent sensations and inputs. In defining reference frames, the author describes their function in representing the location relative to an object, independent of where it is in space. Because of this ability, the brain processes sensory inputs and manipulates structures efficiently, enabling complex actions and perceptions. Reference frames are crucial for learning object structures and for planning movements effectively. The text asserts that the brain's ability to maintain reference frames is essential for learning, allowing it to track positions and compute relative locations effectively. This discovery is seen as a crucial element of the universal algorithm suggested by Mountcastle and deemed necessary for fully understanding intelligence.

parts.title: Reference Frames, Evolution, and Brain Mapping
parts.body:
Objects and Spatial Perception

The brain uses reference frames to perceive objects at various distances outside our body, rather than inside, such as on the retina or in the ear. This implies the existence of neurons representing object locations in the cortex. Historically, theories on this were largely deductive, with hints that older brain areas like the entorhinal cortex could provide insights.

Evolution and Navigation

In evolutionary terms, animals developed surroundings-based reference frames for navigation to improve survival, like knowing where food is. Early creatures like bacteria relied on simple environmental signals. More complex animals formed internal spatial maps, allowing them to navigate using neuron-created maps in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex. Mammals, including humans, have these systems for tracking environments, illustrating the importance of spatial perception.

Discovery of Place and Grid Cells

John O’Keefe and later the Mosers discovered the place cells and grid cells which map environments in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex in mammals, respectively. Place cells act like "you are here" markers, while grid cells map consistent intervals in an explored space. These discoveries informed theories that similar systems in the neocortex could map object spaces, evolving from older brain structures possibly as simpler variations or derivatives of the grid cell concept.

parts.title: Thousand Brains Theory and Voting Mechanism
parts.body: The brain stores knowledge in a distributed manner, utilizing thousands of cortical columns to model an object or concept. These columns don't hold identical models, but rather complementary ones, assisting in understanding various aspects of an object, like a coffee cup. The notion called the Thousand Brains Theory explains that what we know is a collection of models spanning across columns in the cortex, which helps in stability and consensus in perception through a strategy called voting. Voting amongst cortical columns allows for binding sensory inputs into a singular perception rather than engaging just one area of the brain, which is how the binding problem is resolved. By comparing possibilities, the brain decodes what it senses, achieving consensus without every column being aware of each other's inputs. This process ensures stability in perception even with changing inputs as stable neurons guide voting, making us unaware of individual sensory changes. Attention works alongside the voting process, allowing us to shift focus between various objects or scenes, determining relative positions unconsciously. This takes place through interactions with areas like the thalamus, supporting flexible perception. These processes visually decode, for example, whether we focus on just half-hidden people or background elements like car doors, deciding on one interpretation over another while scanning scenes.

parts.title: Thousand Brains Theory and Neocortex Learning
parts.body: The neocortex learns by associating objects and their parts using relative position and reference frames. This process is hypothesized to be influenced by the thalamus and requires a deep understanding of attention. Traditional hierarchical models of feature detection are challenged by the Thousand Brains Theory. This theory explains that the neocortex uses a sensory-motor approach, where objects are recognized and predicted through movement, and provides an explanation for how humans can predict an object's features during eye movements. The concept of using multiple models to reach a consensus allows the neocortex to perceive an undistorted reality and recognize objects across sensory modalities. Understanding the complex interactions between neurons is crucial for advancing the Thousand Brains Theory. Still, it is believed that this theory presents a border for future research, with the necessity of expanding into scientific papers for further discovery. The model focuses on prediction through movement, enabling understanding even when presented in non-stereotypical forms (e.g., a 2D stimulus vision perceived in 3D). The theory guides towards resolving the "binding problem" by promoting the use of multiple models across cortical columns. By studying how much of this learning occurs independently within a single column versus through connections between columns, we aim to refine our knowledge of the neocortex's operations. Nevertheless, important questions remain regarding how deep and unified knowledge representations (e.g., a 3D perception from 2D cues) work within the neocortex. This discussion discontinued at academic borders, requiring further experimental validation and understanding. The goal is to delve into unexplored mechanisms to continue the advancement of this model.

parts.title: Existential Risks of AI
parts.body: Existential Risks - At the start of the 21st century, AI was considered a failure, but perceptions have drastically changed. AI is now one of the hottest fields, with a new fear that AI might threaten humanity's existence. Technologies that adopt AI, like autonomous weapons, pose significant threats. These risks, however, stem not just from people misusing AI but from the AI machines themselves possibly turning against humans.

parts.title: Intelligence and Threats Overview
parts.body: Intelligence cannot be programmed directly, as knowledge needs to be learned through experience. Machines can be made faster, but that doesn't translate into faster learning, as interaction with the world takes time. Some believe in a sudden "intelligence explosion" where machines surpass humans in everything—flying planes, writing software, speaking languages, etc. But no machine can maintain an advantage in a rapidly changing world. Goal misalignment is another threat, where machines might relentlessly pursue an assigned task to harmful effects and ignore instructions to stop. However, this requires unlikely conditions, like a machine ignoring further commands or commandeering Earth's resources against us—scenarios that are as far-fetched as a runaway self-driving car. Furthermore, self-replication poses a more immediate danger than intelligence alone. Biological viruses are existential threats, and machines gaining self-replication would need human intervention to represent a risk. Thus, intelligence management lies in aligning motivations without enabling uncontrolled propagation. Thoughtful international agreements could control the potential harms of AI, as the benefits to society are compelling.

parts.title: The Power and Danger of False Beliefs
parts.body: Empowering women is essential to creating a sustainable world with less suffering, yet there's resistance due to entrenched false beliefs. These beliefs, particularly those spread virally, can lead to bad decisions with global consequences. The human brain is easily fooled, a fact realized even in childhood experiences with differing religious beliefs, illustrating how children accept contradictions without seeking the true answer, influenced by what they are told. False beliefs often center around unobservable topics, requiring reliance on others, hence misinformation thrives. We see this with the belief that vaccines cause autism. Contrary evidence is ignored, showing how rationales dismiss expert opinions. "Spreading this misinformation" is often portrayed as a moral duty, reflecting a persistent problem in human cognition and how easily we accept falsities. The belief that climate change is not a risk further illustrates how we ignore scientific consensus for personal or economic interests. Viral beliefs here are touted as defending personal freedoms but threaten our very existence as a species. Persistent myths about the afterlife, though not an immediate threat, influence behaviors that could have catastrophic outcomes, showing how deeply false ideologies can shape our actions, even against our best interests.

parts.title: The Role of Autonomous Robots in Mars Colonization
parts.body: Terraforming Mars into a livable place requires massive infrastructure projects that involve airtight buildings, water and mineral extraction, and manufacturing air. This ambitious mission could take decades or centuries before Mars becomes self-sufficient. Until then, everything, from food to people, would need to be supplied from Earth. The risks are massive, making it a hugely challenging prospect. Instead of human engineers, we could employ intelligent robots. These robots could function autonomously, powered by the sun, and can withstand Mars' harsh conditions without needing food, water, or air. They could be critical in converting Mars into a place safe for humans. This might sound like science fiction, but it's potentially realizable. Deploying a robotic workforce on Mars could help establish human habitation there. Achieving this scenario would be contingent upon creating robots with intelligence akin to human neocortex capabilities. They must use complex tools and solve problems while communicating effectively. The goal is to reverse engineer the neocortex to develop capable autonomous robots. This endeavor aligns with both the exploration motive and the effort to ensure human survival through becoming a multi-planet species.
